The quality of teaching—Better
use of teaching talents, partly
through etv, frees many school and
college teachers of the necessity of
repeating each lesson to several
class sections, gives them more
time to keep up with their fields,
supervise student activities, meet
with supervisors, correct papers,
and do other tasks for which the
school day leaves little time.
The training of teachers—Teach¬
ing is one of the few professions
whose practitioners rarely see each
other’s work. By permitting teach¬
ers to watch one another in action,
etv is a new avenue to the teacher’s
professional growth. Also, many

lie-detection techniques in arson investigations.
Once, while the course was dealing with child
development and the case of Helen Keller, an
eight-year-old blind and deaf girl and her teacher
consented to come to the studio. The studio was
a strange environment for the girl. She started
walking around, touching things. The camera fol¬
lowed her, giving a kind of powerful immediacy
to the scene that you couldn’t possibly achieve
in a classroom. That sequence was taped, and
three years from now the girl and her teacher
plan to come back. Classes then will have a chance
to see how her development has progressed.
‘ ‘ Televised instruction shifts more responsibility
to the student for learning, instead of his being
spoon-fed. And ETV is not starkly impersonal.
In a way, it goes beyond face-to-face contact be¬
cause it is literally eye to eye. Students have
occasional personal conferences, considerable cor¬
respondence, and frequent telephone talks with
me. Some of our televised courses have arrange¬
ments for discussions with proctors in the class¬
room. Too many questions in the so-called stimu¬
lating interchange in the classroom are simply
clarification of small points. Questions by tele¬
vision students tend to be more fundamental,
indicating that they are clearing up points of fact
themselves and going beyond to the difficult job of
problem solving, reasoning, and analysis.”
